backgroundInformationList.description: Notice of Intention to Remove a Holding Symbol (H) from Zoning By-law 848-2022 - 640 Lansdowne Avenue

noticeDescription:
NOTICE OF INTENTION TO REMOVE A HOLDING SYMBOL (H) FROM ZONING BY-LAW 848-2022

(Under the Planning Act)

 

The City has received the following application under Section 36 of the Planning Act:

 

Application Number: 24 236721 STE 09 OZ

Address: 640 Lansdowne Avenue

Ward: Ward 9 - Davenport

Contact: Kirk Hatcher, Senior Planner at 416-392-0481, by e-mail at Kirk.Hatcher@toronto.ca, or by address 100 Queen Street West, 18th Floor E, Toronto, ON M5H 2N2

 

DESCRIPTION

 

The application to amend Zoning By-law 848-2022 to remove the holding symbol (H) to permit a seven-storey mixed-use building containing 256 long-term care beds, 57 affordable rental dwelling units, and non-residential space on the ground floor fronting Lansdowne Avenue. The By-law included a holding provision that required servicing and land-use compatibility and mitigation measures to be addressed. The location of where the holding symbol (H) would be removed is noted on the map below.

 

Detailed information about the proposal, including background information and materials may be made available for review by contacting the Planner noted above or by visiting the City of Toronto’s https://www.toronto.ca/city-government/planning-development/application-information-centre.  

                 

MAKE YOUR VIEWS KNOWN

 

You may send written comments by mail or email to the Community Planner noted under Contact. Your written comments must be submitted no later than December 6, 2024 to be considered by the Executive Director, Development Review or their designate, Director, Community Planning, Toronto and East York District. A decision by the Executive Director, Development Review or their designate as to whether to remove the holding symbol (H) will occur no earlier than December 10, 2024.

 

Notice to people writing to the City: The City of Toronto Act, 2006, the Planning Act, and the City of Toronto Municipal Code authorize the City of Toronto to collect any personal information in your communication to the City.

 

The City collects this information to enable it to make informed decisions on the relevant issue(s).  If you are submitting letters, e-mails, or other communications to the City, you should be aware that your name and the fact that you communicated with the City will become part of the public record and will appear on the City's website. The City will also make your communication and any personal information in it - such as your postal address, telephone number or e-mail address - available to the public, unless you expressly request the City to remove it.
